Those are all great topics, M44. 
 
 I have often found that good quotes are the perfect "spice" for any speech. Here are a few quotes I have found which might help you, particularly when you argue that the 2nd. Amendment does (and should) protect an individual RKBA:
 
 http://4forums.com/political/showthread.php?p=124621#post124621
 
 If you are dealing with a public policy argument against banning guns, then I suggest you attack the illogical assumption that banning guns will change criminal behavior. Some people who want to ban guns try to use simplistic arguments to suggest that murder rates are tied to the number of guns available for criminal misuse; and they suggest more guns = more crime and less guns = less crime. To counter this argument, use statistics like this:
 
 http://4forums.com/political/showthread.php?p=172278#post172278
 
 If you are not the only one giving a speech, then I also suggest you check to see if anyone will offer a speech in support of gun control. If so, then remember that to make your speech the more effective of the two you don't want to let anything said in a counter-topic speech go unanswered. There are common gun control arguments that float around and tend to be relied upon by proponents of gun control. They are like anti-matter opposites of some of our side's well worn arguments. Let us know and I'm sure someone here can find the right counter for arguments you should expect in a speech advocating gun control. 
 
 In any event I hope some of what I have offered (as well as what others here have posted for you) will give you some solid ammunition for your speech (pun intended). Please fell free to post any other requests for help on these topics. I think you will find most of us on the individual right side of the debate willing to help you any way we can.
 
 Good luck!

Hello,

 But im having difficulty finding strong ideas to back me up.
 
 Could people please give me ideas for my speech?

 Try http://www.a-human-right.com. While somewhat lacking in statistics and quotes, this site makes the point that guns are important to have with an eloquence which I greatly admire. The section on "Why people own guns" isn't full of the statistics that anti-gunners use exclusively. Numbers are meaningless, by and large. It simply makes the point in a way which anyone can understand - and with which only the truly malicious could ever disagree with.
 
 Also, you should seek out the names and some specifics of those (numerous) court cases where it has been ruled that the police are not responsible for providing personal safety, and that they are not responsible for any harm done to an individual by any failure of the police to take some action.
 
 I have chosen to carry a gun because the police are not responsible for my safety. And even if they were, it is exceedingly unlikely that they'd be there when I needed them. I do not intend to be helpless.
 
 Edit:
 I have found a link to an article about one of those cases I mentioned, and a recent one. It even makes the argument: if the police don't have to protect you and your children, don't you have to?
 
 http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,162325,00.html
 Again, my thanks to jyoshu for that one.
 /Edit
 
 Another link which comes to mind - http://www.gunowners.org/skeptic.htm
 
 It is my own view that you should not have your argument based entirely on statistics. Your speech will then be an endless laundry list of meaningless numbers, and no one will want to listen to it. I did the assault weapons ban in my high school debate class - the combination of too many statistics and an average speaking presence did not stand me in good stead. Make sure your arguments are something which people can care about.
 
 Can you tell us more about this speech? Is the topic just "having guns?" If not, than how is it phrased? Did your teacher express any views or recommendations? How long is it? What sort of time frame do you have in? I for one will give as much help as I can. Remember - as long as you have written it yourself, there is no rule against running it past as many people as you can. Not to sound arrogant, but I am especially good with grammar and proper phrasing. I'd be more than happy to proofread for you, if you like. I'm in my third year of college (major is Information Technology), so I have some experience in writing papers, though less so in making speeches/presentaions.

There are a lot of sickos and pedophiles out there. Would your child be better served by having a gun in the house, or by being kidnapped and murdered? Don't tell me it doesn't happen. The number of children kidnapped or killed by criminals has only abstract meaning until one's own is among them. Guns are meaningless in and of themselves. Only innocent lives matter, and there comes a time when force must be used to proect those innocents.

 - irrational fear of weapons,
 - willful disregard for innocent life,
 - the desire to be helpless,
 - and, the fear of responsibility.
